eet%20a%20chosen%20SLA.%20Our%20SLA%20was%201%20second,%20so%20once%20per%20second%20we%20wrote%20updated%20windows%20to%20Redis.%20Spark%20operated%20slightly%20differently%20due%20to%20great%20differences%20in%20its%20design.%20There%E2%80%99s%20more%20details%20on%20that%20in%20the%20Spark%20section.%20Along%20with%20the%20data,%20we%20record%20the%20time%20at%20which%20each%20window%20in%20Redis%20was%20last%20updated.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EAfter%20each%20run,%20a%20utility%20reads%20windows%20from%20Redis%20and%20compares%20the%20windows%E2%80%99%20times%20to%20their%20%3Ci%3Elast_updated_at%3C/i%3E%20times,%20yielding%20a%20latency%20data%20point.%20Because%20the%20last%20event%20for%20a%20window%20cannot%20have%20been%20emitted%20after%20the%20window%20closed%20but%20will%20be%20very%20shortly%20before,%20the%20difference%20between%20a%20window%E2%80%99s%20time%20and%20its%20last_updated_at%20time%20minus%20its%20duration%20represents%20the%20time%20it%20took%20for%20the%20final%20tuple%20in%20a%20window%20to%20go%20from%20Kafka%20to%20Redis%20through%20the%20application.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3E%3Ci%3Ewindow.final_event_latency%20=%20(window.last_updated_at%20%E2%80%93%20window.timestamp)%20%E2%80%93%20window.duration%3C/i%3E%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThis%20is%20a%20bit%20rough,%20but%20this%20benchmark%20was%20not%20purposed%20to%20get%20fine-grained%20numbers%20on%20these%20engines,%20but%20to%20provide%20a%20more%20high-level%20view%20of%20their%20behavior.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EBenchmark%20setup%3C/p%3E%3Cul%3E%3Cli%3E10%20second%20windows%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3E1%20second%20SLA%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3E100%20campaigns%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3E10%20ads%20per%20campaign%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3E5%20Kafka%20nodes%20with%205%20partitions%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3E1%20Redis%20node%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3E10%20worker%20nodes%20(not%20including%20coordination%20nodes%20like%20Storm%E2%80%99s%20Nimbus)%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3E5-10%20Kafka%20producer%20nodes%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3E3%20ZooKeeper%20nodes%3C/li%3E%3C/ul%3E%3Cp%3ESince%20the%20Redis%20node%20in%20our%20architecture%20only%20performs%20in-memory%20lookups%20using%20a%20well-optimized%20hashing%20scheme,%20it%20did%20not%20become%20a%20bottleneck.%20The%20nodes%20are%20homogeneously%20configured,%20each%20with%20two%20Intel%20E5530%20processors%20running%20at%202.4GHz,%20with%20a%20total%20of%2016%20cores%20(8%20physical,%2016%20hyperthreading)%20per%20node.%20Each%20node%20has%2024GiB%20of%20memory,%20and%20the%20machines%20are%20all%20located%20within%20the%20same%20rack,%20connected%20through%20a%20gigabit%20Ethernet%20switch.%20The%20cluster%20has%20a%20total%20of%2040%20nodes%20available.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EWe%20ran%20multiple%20instances%20of%20the%20Kafka%20producers%20to%20create%20the%20required%20load%20since%20individual%20producers%20begin%20to%20fall%20behind%20at%20around%2017,000%20events%20per%20second.%20In%20total,%20we%20use%20anywhere%20between%2020%20to%2025%20nodes%20in%20this%20benchmark.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20use%20of%2010%20workers%20for%20a%20topology%20is%20near%20the%20average%20number%20we%20see%20being%20used%20by%20topologies%20internal%20to%20Yahoo.%20Of%20course,%20our%20Storm%20clusters%20are%20larger%20in%20size,%20but%20they%20are%20multi-tenant%20and%20run%20many%20topologies.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3ETo%20begin%20the%20benchmarks%20Kafka%20is%20cleared,%20Redis%20is%20populated%20with%20initial%20data%20(%3Ci%3Ead_id%3C/i%3E%20to%20%3Ci%3Ecampaign_id%3C/i%3E%20mapping),%20the%20streaming%20job%20is%20started,%20and%20then%20after%20a%20bit%20of%20time%20to%20let%20the%20job%20finish%20launching,%20the%20producers%20are%20started%20with%20instructions%20to%20produce%20events%20at%20a%20particular%20rate,%20giving%20the%20desired%20aggregate%20throughput.%20The%20system%20was%20left%20to%20run%20for%2030%20minutes%20before%20the%20producers%20were%20shut%20down.%20A%20few%20seconds%20were%20allowed%20for%20all%20events%20to%20be%20processed%20before%20the%20streaming%20job%20itself%20was%20stopped.%20The%20benchmark%20utility%20was%20then%20run%20to%20generate%20a%20file%20containing%20a%20list%20of%20%3Ci%3Ewindow.last_updated_at%20%E2%80%93%20window.timestamp%3C/i%3E%20numbers.%20These%20files%20were%20saved%20for%20each%20throughput%20we%20tested%20and%20then%20were%20used%20to%20generate%20the%20charts%20in%20this%20document.%3C/p%3E%3Ch2%3E%3Cb%3EFlink%3C/b%3E%3C/h2%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20benchmark%20for%20Flink%20was%20implemented%20in%20Java%20by%20using%20Flink%E2%80%99s%20DataStream%20API.%20%C2%A0The%20Flink%20DataStream%20API%20has%20many%20similarities%20to%20Storm%E2%80%99s%20streaming%20API.%20%C2%A0For%20both%20Flink%20and%20Storm,%20the%20dataflow%20can%20be%20represented%20as%20a%20directed%20graph.%20Each%20vertex%20is%20a%20user%20defined%20operator%20and%20each%20directed%20edge%20represents%20a%20flow%20of%20data.%20%C2%A0Storm%E2%80%99s%20API%20uses%20spouts%20and%20bolts%20as%20its%20operators%20while%20Flink%20uses%20map,%20flatMap,%20as%20well%20as%20many%20pre-built%20operators%20such%20as%20filter,%20project,%20and%20reduce.%20Flink%20uses%20a%20mechanism%20called%20checkpointing%20to%20guarantee%20processing.%20Unless%20checkpointing%20is%20used%20in%20the%20Flink%20job,%20Flink%20offers%20at%20most%20once%20processing%20similar%20to%20Storm%20with%20acking%20turned%20on.%20%C2%A0For%20the%20Flink%20benchmark%20we%20did%20not%20use%20checkpointing.%20%C2%A0Notable%20configs%20we%20used%20in%20Flink%20is%20listed%20below:%3C/p%3E%3Cul%3E%3Cli%3Etaskmanager.heap.mb:%2015360%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3Etaskmanager.numberOfTaskSlots:%2016%3C/li%3E%3C/ul%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20Flink%20version%20of%20the%20benchmark%20uses%20the%20FlinkKafkaConsumer%20to%20read%20data%20in%20from%20Kafka.%20%C2%A0The%20data%20read%20in%20from%20Kafka%E2%80%94which%20is%20in%20a%20JSON%20formatted%20string%E2%80%94%20is%20then%20deserialized%20and%20parsed%20by%20a%20custom%20defined%20flatMap%20operator.%20Once%20deserialized,%20the%20data%20is%20filtered%20via%20a%20custom%20defined%20filter%20operator.%20Afterwards,%20the%20filtered%20data%20is%20projected%20by%20using%20the%20project%20operator.%20From%20there,%20the%20data%20is%20joined%20with%20data%20in%20Redis%20by%20a%20custom%20defined%20flapMap%20function.%20Lastly,%20the%20final%20results%20are%20calculated%20from%20the%20data%20and%20written%20to%20redis.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20rate%20at%20which%20Kafka%20emitted%20data%20events%20into%20the%20Flink%20benchmark%20is%20varied%20from%2050,000%20events/sec%20to%20170,000%20events/sec.%20For%20each%20Kafka%20emit%20rate,%20the%20percentile%20latency%20for%20a%20tuple%20to%20be%20completely%20processed%20in%20the%20Flink%20benchmark%20is%20illustrated%20in%20the%20graph%20below.%3C/p%3E%3Cfigure%20class=%22tmblr-full%22%20data-orig-height=%22365%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/ad625d5307b79ab4fab204c7fde1b733/tumblr_inline_nzet5oeYfc1spdvr2_540.png%22%3E%3Cimg%20alt=%22%22%20src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/a32a2d127b8a07ec02b12fd18a77ee41/tumblr_inline_pecnpmUhEO1t17fny_540.png%22%20data-orig-height=%22365%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/ad625d5307b79ab4fab204c7fde1b733/tumblr_inline_nzet5oeYfc1spdvr2_540.png%22/%3E%3C/figure%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20percentile%20latency%20for%20all%20Kafka%20emit%20rates%20are%20relatively%20the%20same.%20The%20percentile%20latency%20rises%20linearly%20until%20around%20the%2099th%20percentile,%20where%20the%20latency%20appears%20to%20increase%20exponentially.%20%C2%A0%3C/p%3E%3Ch2%3E%3Cb%3ESpark%3C/b%3E%3C/h2%3E%3Cp%3EFor%20the%20Spark%20benchmark,%20the%20code%20was%20written%20in%20Scala.%20Since%20the%20micro-batching%20methodology%20of%20Spark%20is%20different%20than%20the%20pure%20streaming%20nature%20of%20Storm,%20we%20needed%20to%20rethink%20parts%20of%20the%20benchmark.%20Storm%20and%20Flink%20benchmarks%20would%20update%20the%20Redis%20database%20once%20a%20second%20to%20try%20and%20meet%20our%20SLA,%20keeping%20the%20intermediate%20update%20values%20in%20a%20local%20cache.%20As%20a%20result,%20the%20batch%20duration%20in%20the%20Spark%20streaming%20version%20was%20set%20to%201%20second,%20at%20least%20for%20smaller%20amounts%20of%20traffic.%20We%20had%20to%20increase%20the%20batch%20duration%20for%20larger%20throughputs.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20benchmark%20is%20written%20in%20a%20typical%20Spark%20style%20using%20DStreams.%20DStreams%20are%20the%20streaming%20equivalent%20of%20regular%20RDDs,%20and%20create%20a%20separate%20RDD%20for%20every%20micro%20batch.%20Note%20that%20in%20the%20subsequent%20discussion,%20we%20use%20the%20term%20%E2%80%9CRDD%E2%80%9D%20instead%20of%20%E2%80%9CDStream%E2%80%9D%20to%20refer%20to%20the%20RDD%20representation%20of%20the%20DStream%20in%20the%20currently%20active%20microbatch.%20Processing%20begins%20with%20the%20direct%20Kafka%20consumer%20included%20with%20Spark%201.5.%20Since%20the%20Kafka%20input%20data%20in%20our%20benchmark%20is%20stored%20in%205%20partitions,%20this%20Kafka%20consumer%20creates%20a%20DStream%20with%205%20partitions%20as%20well.%20After%20that,%20a%20number%20of%20transformations%20are%20applied%20on%20the%20DStreams,%20including%20maps%20and%20filters.%20The%20transformation%20involving%20joining%20data%20with%20Redis%20is%20a%20special%20case.%20Since%20we%20do%20not%20want%20to%20create%20a%20separate%20connection%20to%20Redis%20for%20each%20record,%20we%20use%20a%20mapPartitions%20operation%20that%20can%20give%20control%20of%20a%20whole%20RDD%20partition%20to%20our%20code.%20%C2%A0This%20way,%20we%20create%20one%20connection%20to%20Redis%20and%20use%20this%20single%20connection%20to%20query%20information%20from%20Redis%20for%20all%20the%20events%20in%20that%20RDD%20partition.%20The%20same%20approach%20is%20used%20later%20when%20we%20update%20the%20final%20results%20in%20Redis.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EIt%20should%20be%20noted%20that%20our%20writes%20to%20Redis%20were%20implemented%20as%20a%20side-effect%20of%20the%20execution%20of%20the%20RDD%20transformation%20in%20order%20to%20keep%20the%20benchmark%20simple,%20so%20this%20would%20not%20be%20compatible%20with%20exactly-once%20semantics.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EWe%20found%20that%20with%20high%20enough%20throughput,%20Spark%20was%20not%20able%20to%20keep%20up.%20%C2%A0At%20100,000%20messages%20per%20second%20the%20latency%20greatly%20increased.%20We%20considered%20adjustments%20along%20two%20control%20dimensions%20to%20help%20Spark%20cope%20with%20increasing%20throughput.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20first%20is%20the%20microbatch%20duration.%20This%20is%20a%20control%20dimension%20that%20is%20not%20present%20in%20a%20pure%20streaming%20system%20like%20Storm.%20Increasing%20the%20duration%20increases%20latency%20while%20reducing%20overhead%20and%20therefore%20increasing%20maximum%20throughput.%20The%20challenge%20is%20that%20the%20choice%20of%20the%20optimal%20batch%20duration%20that%20minimizes%20latency%20while%20allowing%20spark%20to%20handle%20the%20throughput%20is%20a%20time%20consuming%20process.%20Essentially,%20we%20have%20to%20set%20a%20batch%20duration,%20run%20the%20benchmark%20for%2030%20minutes,%20check%20the%20results%20and%20decrease/increase%20the%20duration.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20second%20dimension%20is%20parallelism.%20However,%20increasing%20parallelism%20is%20simpler%20said%20than%20done%20in%20the%20case%20of%20Spark.%20For%20a%20true%20streaming%20system%20like%20Storm,%20one%20bolt%20instance%20can%20send%20its%20results%20to%20any%20number%20of%20subsequent%20bolt%20instances%20by%20using%20a%20random%20shuffle.%20To%20scale,%20one%20can%20increase%20the%20parallelism%20of%20the%20second%20bolt.%20In%20the%20case%20of%20a%20micro%20batch%20system%20like%20Spark,%20we%20need%20to%20perform%20a%20reshuffle%20operation%20similar%20to%20how%20intermediate%20data%20in%20a%20Hadoop%20MapReduce%20program%20are%20shuffled%20and%20merged%20across%20the%20cluster.%20But%20the%20reshuffling%20itself%20introduces%20considerable%20overhead.%20Initially,%20we%20thought%20our%20operations%20were%20CPU-bound,%20and%20so%20the%20benefits%20of%20reshuffling%20to%20a%20higher%20number%20of%20partitions%20would%20outweigh%20the%20cost%20of%20reshuffling.%20%C2%A0Instead,%20we%20found%20the%20bottleneck%20to%20be%20scheduling,%20and%20so%20reshuffling%20only%20added%20overhead.%20We%20suspect%20that%20at%20higher%20throughput%20rates%20or%20with%20operations%20that%20are%20CPU-bound,%20the%20reverse%20would%20be%20true.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20final%20results%20are%20interesting.%20There%20are%20essentially%20three%20behaviors%20for%20a%20Spark%20workload%20depending%20on%20the%20window%20duration.%20First,%20if%20the%20batch%20duration%20is%20set%20sufficiently%20large,%20the%20majority%20of%20the%20events%20will%20be%20handled%20within%20the%20current%20micro%20batch.%20The%20following%20figure%20shows%20the%20resulting%20percentile%20processing%20graph%20for%20this%20case%20(100K%20events,%2010%20seconds%20batch%20duration).%3C/p%3E%3Cfigure%20class=%22tmblr-full%22%20data-orig-height=%22370%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/9f1f17e7ea760b5a1fc65f135b426a46/tumblr_inline_nzet5rxBg81spdvr2_540.png%22%3E%3Cimg%20alt=%22%22%20src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/9a8a7ef36080b0c49dbd874dbce82e82/tumblr_inline_pecnpm7Xbp1t17fny_540.png%22%20data-orig-height=%22370%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/9f1f17e7ea760b5a1fc65f135b426a46/tumblr_inline_nzet5rxBg81spdvr2_540.png%22/%3E%3C/figure%3E%3Cp%3EBut%20whenever%2090%%20of%20events%20are%20processed%20in%20the%20first%20batch,%20there%20is%20possibility%20of%20improving%20latency.%20By%20reducing%20the%20batch%20duration%20sufficiently,%20we%20get%20into%20a%20region%20where%20the%20incoming%20events%20are%20processed%20within%203%20or%204%20subsequent%20batches.%20This%20is%20the%20second%20behavior,%20in%20which%20the%20batch%20duration%20puts%20the%20system%20on%20the%20verge%20of%20falling%20behind,%20but%20is%20still%20manageable,%20a benchmark,%20and%20as%20a%20result%20we%20disabled%20it.%3C/p%3E%3Cfigure%20class=%22tmblr-full%22%20data-orig-height=%22369%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/a6bc6c128e64a117f8d068e78b1ded60/tumblr_inline_nzet5r68Um1spdvr2_540.png%22%3E%3Cimg%20alt=%22%22%20src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/6fcbbf78a4b9a7db6d5b1a6c49c4240b/tumblr_inline_pecnpnD96v1t17fny_540.png%22%20data-orig-height=%22369%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/a6bc6c128e64a117f8d068e78b1ded60/tumblr_inline_nzet5r68Um1spdvr2_540.png%22/%3E%3C/figure%3E%3Cfigure%20class=%22tmblr-full%22%20data-orig-height=%22367%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/6884852b7619285bbd93e17efe7e1832/tumblr_inline_nzet5sebGd1spdvr2_540.png%22%3E%3Cimg%20alt=%22%22%20src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/dc67479ae9f954720963d94493d682f9/tumblr_inline_pecnpnymmK1t17fny_540.png%22%20data-orig-height=%22367%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/6884852b7619285bbd93e17efe7e1832/tumblr_inline_nzet5sebGd1spdvr2_540.png%22/%3E%3C/figure%3E%3Cp%3E%3Ci%3E%3Cb%3EPerformance%20without%20back%20pressure%20(top),%20and%20with%20back%20pressure%20enabled%20(bottom).%20The%20latencies%20with%20the%20back%20pressure%20enabled%20are%20worse%20(70%20seconds%20vs%20120%20seconds).%20Note%20that%20both%20of%20these%20results%20are%20unacceptable%20for%20a%20streaming%20system%20as%20both%20fall%20behind%20the%20incoming%20data.%20Batch%20duration%20was%20set%20to%202%20seconds%20for%20each%20run,%20with%20130,000%20throughput.%3C/b%3E%3C/i%3E%3C/p%3E%3Ch2%3E%3Cb%3EStorm%3C/b%3E%3C/h2%3E%3Cp%3EStorm%E2%80%99s%20benchmark%20was%20written%20using%20the%20Java%20API.%20We%20tested%20both%20Apache%20Storm%200.10.0%20release%20and%20a%200.11.0%20snapshot.%20The%20snapshot%E2%80%99s%20commit%20hash%20was%20a8d253a.%20One%20worker%20process%20per%20host%20was%20used,%20and%20each%20worker%20was%20given%2016%20tasks%20to%20run%20in%2016%20executors%20-%20one%20for%20each%20core.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EStorm%200.10.0:%3C/p%3E%3Cfigure%20class=%22tmblr-full%22%20data-orig-height=%22368%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/4bb815ba6ae9e8ca100f753effd78d38/tumblr_inline_nzet5rcFDo1spdvr2_540.png%22%3E%3Cimg%20alt=%22%22%20src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/33ab569f8d0e4e9c4613aad1aad753b4/tumblr_inline_pecnpoduG61t17fny_540.png%22%20data-orig-height=%22368%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/4bb815ba6ae9e8ca100f753effd78d38/tumblr_inline_nzet5rcFDo1spdvr2_540.png%22/%3E%3C/figure%3E%3Cp%3EStorm%200.11.0:%3C/p%3E%3Cfigure%20class=%22tmblr-full%22%20data-orig-height=%22368%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/5f611487a173ab399ed20ca7ad189bc7/tumblr_inline_nzet5oN3y51spdvr2_540.png%22%3E%3Cimg%20alt=%22%22%20src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/9255fe4023b25e55db88ace3888c2c9d/tumblr_inline_pecnppMNnm1t17fny_540.png%22%20data-orig-height=%22368%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/5f611487a173ab399ed20ca7ad189bc7/tumblr_inline_nzet5oN3y51spdvr2_540.png%22/%3E%3C/figure%3E%3Cp%3EStorm%20compared%20favorably%20to%20both%20Flink%20and%20Spark%20Streaming.%20Storm%200.11.0%20beat%20Storm%200.10.0,%20showing%20the%20optimizations%20that%20have%20gone%20in%20since%20the%200.10.0%20release.%20However,%20at%20high-throughput%20both%20versions%20of%20Storm%20struggled.%20Storm%200.10.0%20was%20not%20able%20to%20handle%20throughputs%20above%20135,000%20events%20per%20second.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EStorm%200.11.0%20performed%20similarly%20until%20we%20disabled%20acking.%20In%20the%20benchmarking%20topology,%20acking%20was%20used%20for%20flow%20control%20but%20not%20for%20processing%20guarantees.%20In%200.11.0,%20Storm%20added%20a%20simple%20back%20pressure%20controller,%20allowing%20us%20to%20avoid%20the%20overhead%20of%20ac 365%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/09114914eb9baead2d40b782742c5e72/tumblr_inline_nzet5oLKk51spdvr2_540.png%22%3E%3Cimg%20alt=%22%22%20src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/034b6bfeff359d1e12545a6a38563a25/tumblr_inline_pecnpr7Kxo1t17fny_540.png%22%20data-orig-height=%22365%22%20data-orig-width=%22540%22%20data-orig-src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/09114914eb9baead2d40b782742c5e72/tumblr_inline_nzet5oLKk51spdvr2_540.png%22/%3E%3C/figure%3E%3Cp%3EWe%20did%20not%20include%20the%20results%20for%20Storm%200.10.0%20and%200.11.0%20with%20acking%20enabled%20beyond%20135,000%20events%20per%20second,%20because%20they%20could%20not%20keep%20up%20with%20the%20throughput.%20The%20resulting%20graph%20had%20the%20final%20point%20for%20Storm%200.10.0%20in%20the%2045,000%20ms%20range,%20dwarfing%20every%20other%20line%20on%20the%20graph.%20The%20longer%20the%20topology%20ran,%20the%20higher%20the%20latencies%20got,%20indicating%20that%20it%20was%20losing%20ground.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EAll%20of%20these%20benchmarks%20except%20where%20otherwise%20noted%20were%20performed%20using%20default%20settings%20for%20Storm,%20Spark,%20and%20Flink,%20and%20we%20focused%20on%20writing%20correct,%20easy%20to%20understand%20programs%20without%20optimizing%20each%20to%20its%20full%20potential.%20Because%20of%20this%20each%20of%20the%20six%20steps%20were%20a%20separate%20bolt%20or%20spout.%20Flink%20and%20Spark%20both%20do%20operator%20combining%20automatically,%20but%20Storm%20(without%20Trident)%20does%20not.%20What%20this%20means%20for%20Storm%20is%20that%20events%20go%20through%20many%20more%20steps%20and%20have%20a%20higher%20overhead%20compared%20to%20the%20other%20systems.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EIn%20addition%20to%20further%20optimizations%20to%20Storm,%20we%20would%20like%20to%20expand%20the%20benchmark%20in%20terms%20of%20functionality,%20and%20to%20include%20other%20stream%20processing%20systems%20like%20Samza%20and%20Apex.%20We%20would%20also%20like%20to%20ta to%20a%20user%20based%20on%20the%20dot%20product%20between%20the%20user%20and%20documents%20latent%20factors.%20An%20obvious%20problem%20with%20this%20approach%20is%20that%20new%20users%20and%20new%20documents%20will%20not%20have%20those%20latent%20factors%20available%20to%20them.%20This%20is%20what%20is%20called%20a%20cold%20start%20problem%20and%20will%20be%20addressed%20with%20content-based%20techniques%20described%20in%20future%20posts.%3C/p%3E%3Ch2%3EEvaluation%20metrics%3C/h2%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20evaluation%20metric%20used%20by%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://www.kaggle.com/c/predict-wordpress-likes/details/evaluation%22%3EKaggle%3C/a%3E%20for%20this%20challenge%20was%20the%20Mean%20Average%20Precision%20at%20100%20(MAP@100).%20However,%20since%20we%20do%20not%20have%20information%20about%20which%20blog%20posts%20the%20users%20did%20not%20like%20(that%20is,%20we%20have%20only%20positive%20feedback)%20and%20our%20inability%20to%20obtain%20user%20behavior%20to%20the%20recommendations%20we%20make%20(this%20is%20an%20offline%20evaluation,%20different%20from%20the%20usual%20A/B%20testing%20performed%20by%20companies%20that%20use%20recommendation%20systems),%20we%20offer%20a%20similar%20remark%20as%20the%20one%20included%20in%20(Hu%20et.%20al.%202008)%20and%20prefer%20recall-oriented%20measures.%20Following%20(Hu%20et.%20al.%202008)%20we%20will%20use%20the%20expected%20percentile%20ranking.%3C/p%3E%3Ch2%3EEvaluation%20Framework%3C/h2%3E%3Cp%3E%3Cb%3EGenerate%20training%20and%20test%20sets%3C/b%3E%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EIn%20order%20to%20evaluate%20the%20gains%20obtained%20by%20the%20recommendation%20system%20when%20we%20start%20to%20improve%20it%20with%20more%20accurate%20algorithms,%20we%20will%20split%20the%20dataset%20we%20have%20available%20into%20training%20and%20test%20sets.%20The%20training%20set%20will%20contain%20document%20(blog%20post)%20and%20user%20action%20(likes)%20pairs%20as%20well%20as%20any%20information%20available%20about%20the%20documents%20contained%20in%20the%20training%20set.%20There%20is%20no%20additional%20information%20about%20the%20users%20besides%20the%20blog%20posts%20they%20have%20liked.%20The%20test%20set%20will%20be%20formed%20by%20a%20series%20of%20documents%20available%20to%20be%20recommended%20and%20a%20set%20of%20users%20to%20whom%20we%20need%20to%20make%20recommendations.%20This%20list%20of%20test%20set%20documents%20constitutes%20the%20Vespa%20content%20pool,%20which%20is%20the%20set%20of%20documents%20stored%20in%20Vespa%20that%20are%20available%20to%20be%20served%20to%20users.%20The%20user%20actions%20will%20be%20hidden%20from%20the%20test%20set%20and%20used%20later%20to%20evaluate%20the%20recommendations%20made%20by%20Vespa.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3ETo%20create%20an%20application%20that%20more%20closely%20resembles%20the%20challenges%20faced%20by%20companies%20when%20building%20their%20recommendation%20systems,%20we%20decided%20to%20construct%20the%20training%20and%20test%20sets%20in%20such%20a%20way%20that:%3C/p%3E%3Cul%3E%3Cli%3EThere%20will%20be%20blog%20posts%20that%20had%20been%20liked%20in%20the%20training%20set%20by%20a%20set%20of%20users%20and%20that%20had%20also%20been%20liked%20in%20the%20test%20set%20by%20another%20set%20of%20users,%20even%20though%20this%20information%20will%20be%20hidden%20in%20the%20test%20set.%20Those%20cases%20are%20interesting%20to%20evaluate%20if%20the%20exploitation%20(as%20opposed%20to%20exploration)%20component%20of%20the%20system%20is%20working%20well.%20That%20is,%20if%20we%20are%20able%20to%20identify%20high%20quality%20blog%20posts%20based%20on%20the%20available%20information%20during%20training%20and%20exploit%20this%20knowledge%20by%20recommending%20those%20high%20quality%20blog%20posts%20to%20another%20set%20of%20users%20that%20might%20like%20them%20as%20well.%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3EThere%20will%20be%20blog%20posts%20in%20the%20test%20set%20that%20had%20never%20been%20seen%20in%20the%20training%20set.%20Those%20cases%20are%20interesting%20in%20order%20to%20evaluate%20how%20the%20system%20deals%20with%20the%20cold-start%20problem.%20Systems%20that%20are%20too%20biased%20towards%20exploitation%20will%20fail%20to%20recommend%20new%20and%20unexplored%20blog%20posts,%20leading%20to%20a%20feedback%20loop%20that%20will%20cause%20the%20system%20to%20focus%20into%20a%20small%20share%20of%20the%20available%20content.%3C/li%3E%3C/ul%3E%3Cp%3EA%20key%20challenge%20faced%20by%20recommender%20system%20designers%20is%20how%20to%20balance%20the%20exploitation/exploration%20components%20of%20their%20system,%20and%20our%20training/test%20set%20split%20outlined%20above%20will%20try%20to%20replicate%20this%20challenge%20in%20our%20application.%20Notice%20that%20this%20split%20is%20different%20from%20the%20approach%20taken%20by%20the%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://www.kaggle.com/c/predict-wordpress-likes%22%3EKaggle%20competition%3C/a%3E%20where%20the%20blog%20posts%20available%20in%20the%20test%20set%20had%20never%20been%20seen%20in%20the%20training%20set,%20which%20removes%20the%20exploitation%20component%20of%20the%20equation.%3Cbr/%3E%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20Spark%20job%20uses%20%3Ccode%3EtrainPosts.json%3C/code%3E%20and%20creates%20the%20folders%20%3Ccode%3Eblog-job/training_set_ids%3C/code%3E%20and%20%3Ccode%3Eblog-job/test_set_ids%3C/code%3E%20containing%20files%20with%20%3Ccode%3Epost_id%3C/code%3E%20and%20%3Ccode%3Euser_id%3C/code%3Epairs:%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3E$%20cd%20blog-recommendation;%20export%20SPARK_LOCAL_IP=%22127.0.0.1%22$%20spark-submit%20--class%20%22com.yahoo.example.blog.BlogRecommendationApp%22%20\%20%C2%A0--master%20local[4]%20../blog-tutorial-shared/target/scala-*/blog-support*.jar%20\%20%C2%A0--task%20split_set%20--input_file%20../trainPosts.json%20\%20%C2%A0--test_perc_stage1%200.05%20--test_perc_stage2%200.20%20--seed%20123%20\%20%C2%A0--output_path%20blog-job/training_and_test_indices%3C/code%3E%3C/pre%3E%3Cul%3E%3Cli%3Etest_perc_stage1:%20The%20percentage%20of%20the%20blog%20posts%20that%20will%20be%20located%20only%20on%20the%20test%20set%20(exploration%20component).%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3Etest_perc_stage2:%20The%20percentage%20of%20the%20remaining%20(post_id,%20user_id)%20pairs%20that%20should%20be%20moved%20to%20the%20test%20set%20(exploitation%20component).%3C/li%3E%3Cli%3Eseed:%20seed%20value%20used%20in%20order%20to%20replicate%20results%20if%20required.%3C/li%3E%3C/ul%3E%3Cp%3E%3Cb%3ECompute%20user%20and%20item%20latent%20factors%3C/b%3E%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EUse%20the%20complete%20training%20set%20to%20compute%20user%20and%20item%20latent%20factors.%20We%20will%20leave%20the%20discussion%20about%20tuning%20and%20performance%20improvement%20of%20the%20model%20used%20to%20the%20section%20about%20model%20tuning%20and%20offline%20evaluation.%20Submit%20the%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://github.com/vespa-engine/sample-apps/tree/master/blog-tutorial-shared#building-and-running-the-spark-script-for-calculating-latent-factors%22%3ESpark%20job%3C/a%3E%20to%20compute%20the%20user%20and%20item%20latent%20factors:%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3E$%20spark-submit%20--class%20%22com.yahoo.example.blog.BlogRecommendationApp%22%20\%20%C2%A0--master%20local[4]%20../blog-tutorial-shared/target/scala-*/blog-support*.jar%20\%20%C2%A0--task%20collaborative_filtering%20\%20%C2%A0--input_file%20blog-job/training_and_test_indices/training_set_ids%20\%20%C2%A0--rank%2010%20--numIterations%2010%20--lambda%200.01%20\%20%C2%A0--output_path%20blog-job/user_item_cf%3C/code%3E%3C/pre%3E%3Cp%3EVerify%20the%20vectors%20for%20the%20latent%20factors%20for%20users%20and%20posts:%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3E$%20head%20-1%20blog-job/user_item_cf/user_features/part-00000%20|%20python%20-m%20json.tool{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%22user_id%22:%20270,%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%22user_item_cf%22:%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%22user_item_cf:0%22:%20-1.750116e-05,%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%22user_item_cf:1%22:%209.730623e-05,%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%22user_item_cf:2%22:%208.515047e-05,%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%22user_item_cf:3%22:%206.9 king%20expressions%20of%20such%20complexity%20at%20scale.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EVespa%20comes%20with%20a%20Tensor%20framework,%20which%20unify%20and%20generalizes%20scalar,%20vector%20and%20matrix%20operations,%20handles%20the%20sparseness%20inherent%20to%20most%20machine%20learning%20application%20(most%20cases%20evaluated%20by%20the%20model%20is%20lacking%20values%20for%20most%20of%20the%20features)%20and%20allow%20for%20models%20to%20be%20continuously%20updated.%20Additional%20information%20about%20the%20Tensor%20framework%20can%20be%20found%20in%20the%20%3Ca%20href=%22http://docs.vespa.ai/documentation/tensor-user-guide.html%22%3Etensor%20user%20guide%3C/a%3E.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EWe%20want%20to%20have%20those%20latent%20factors%20available%20in%20a%20Tensor%20representation%20to%20be%20used%20during%20ranking%20by%20the%20Tensor%20framework.%20A%20tensor%20field%20%3Ccode%3Euser_item_cf%3C/code%3E%20is%20added%20to%20%3Ccode%3Eblog_post.sd%3C/code%3E%20to%20hold%20the%20blog%20post%20latent%20factor:%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3Efield%20user_item_cf%20type%20tensor(user_item_cf[10])%20{indexing:%20summary%20|%20attributeattribute:%20tensor(user_item_cf[10])}field%20has_user_item_cf%20type%20byte%20{indexing:%20summary%20|%20attributeattribute:%20fast-search}%3C/code%3E%3C/pre%3E%3Cp%3EA%20new%20search%20definition%20%3Ccode%3Euser.sd%3C/code%3E%20defines%20a%20document%20type%20named%20%3Ccode%3Euser%3C/code%3E%20to%20hold%20information%20for%20users:%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3Esearch%20user%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0document%20user%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0field%20user_id%20type%20string%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0indexing:%20summary%20|%20attribute%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0attribute:%20fast-search%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0field%20has_read_items%20type%20array&lt;string&gt;%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0indexing:%20summary%20|%20attribute%2 .WordItem;import%20com.yahoo.processing.request.CompoundName;import%20com.yahoo.search.Query;import%20com.yahoo.search.Result;import%20com.yahoo.search.Searcher;import%20com.yahoo.search.querytransform.QueryTreeUtil;import%20com.yahoo.search.result.Hit;import%20com.yahoo.search.searchchain.Execution;import%20com.yahoo.search.searchchain.SearchChain;import%20com.yahoo.tensor.Tensor;import%20java.util.ArrayList;import%20java.util.Iterator;import%20java.util.List;public%20class%20UserProfileSearcher%20extends%20Searcher%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0public%20Result%20search(Query%20query,%20Execution%20execution)%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0//%20Get%20tensor%20and%20read%20items%20from%20user%20profile%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0Object%20userIdProperty%20=%20query.properties().get(%22user_id%22);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0if%20(userIdProperty%20!=%20null)%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0Hit%20userProfile%20=%20retrieveUserProfile(userIdProperty.toString(),%20execution);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0if%20(userProfile%20!=%20null)%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0addUserProfileTensorToQuery(query,%20userProfile);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0NotItem%20notItem%20=%20new%20NotItem();%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0notItem.addItem(new%20IntItem(1,%20%22has_user_item_cf%22));%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0for%20(String%20item%20:%20getReadItems(userProfile.getField(%22has_read_items%22))){%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0notItem.addItem(new%20WordItem(item,%20%22post_id%22));%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0QueryTreeUtil.andQueryItemWithRoot(query,%20notItem);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0//%20Restric%20to%20search%20in%20blog_posts%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0query.getModel().setRestrict(%22blog_post%22);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0//%20Rank%20blog%20posts%20using%20tensor%20rank%20profile%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0if(query.properties().get(%22ranking%22)%20==%20null)%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0query.properties().set(new%20CompoundName(%22ranking%22),%20%22tensor%22);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0return%20execution.search(query);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0private%20Hit%20retrieveUserProfile(String%20userId,%20Execution%20execution)%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0Query%20query%20=%20new%20Query();%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0query.getModel().setRestrict(%22user%22);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0query.getModel().getQueryTree().setRoot(new%20WordItem(userId,%20%22user_id%22));%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0query.setHits(1);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0SearchChain%20vespaChain%20=%20execution.searchChainRegistry().getComponent(%22vespa%22);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0Result%20result%20=%20new%20Execution(vespaChain,%20execution.context()).search(query);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0execution.fill(result);%20//%20This%20is%20needed%20to%20get%20the%20actual%20summary%20data%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0Iterator&lt;Hit&gt;%20hiterator%20=%20result.hits().deepIterator();%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0return%20hiterator.hasNext()%20?%20hiterator.next()%20:%20null;%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0private%20void%20addUserProfileTensorToQuery(Query%20query,%20Hit%20userProfile)%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0Object%20userItemCf%20=%20userProfile.getField(%22user_item_cf%22);%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0if%20(userItemCf%20!=%20null)%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20% mailto:?subject=Blog%20recommendation%20with%20neural%20network%20models&body=%3Ch2%3EIntroduction%3C/h2%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20main%20objective%20of%20this%20post%20is%20to%20show%20how%20to%20deploy%20neural%20network%20models%20in%20Vespa%20using%20our%20Tensor%20Framework.%20In%20fact,%20any%20model%20that%20can%20be%20represented%20by%20a%20series%20of%20Tensor%20operations%20can%20be%20deployed%20in%20Vespa.%20Neural%20networks%20is%20just%20a%20popular%20example.%20In%20addition,%20we%20will%20introduce%20the%20multi-phase%20ranking%20model%20available%20in%20Vespa%20that%20can%20be%20used%20to%20run%20more%20expensive%20models%20in%20a%20phase%20based%20on%20a%20reduced%20number%20of%20documents%20returned%20by%20previous%20phases.%20This%20feature%20allow%20us%20to%20run%20models%20that%20would%20be%20prohibitively%20expensive%20to%20use%20if%20we%20had%20to%20run%20them%20at%20query-time%20across%20all%20the%20documents%20indexed%20in%20Vespa.%3C/p%3E%3Ch2%3EModel%20Training%3C/h2%3E%3Cp%3EIn%20this%20section,%20we%20will%20define%20a%20neural%20network%20model,%20show%20how%20we%20created%20a%20suitable%20dataset%20to%20train%20the%20model%20and%20train%20the%20model%20using%20TensorFlow.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3E%3Cb%3EThe%20neural%20network%20model%3C/b%3E%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EIn%20the%20previous%20blog%20post,%20we%20computed%20latent%20factors%20for%20each%20user%20and%20each%20document%20and%20then%20used%20a%20dot-product%20between%20user%20and%20document%20vectors%20to%20rank%20the%20documents%20available%20for%20recommendation%20to%20a%20specific%20user.%20In%20this%20tutorial%20we%20will%20train%20a%202-layer%20fully%20connected%20neural%20network%20model%20that%20will%20take%20the%20same%20user%20(%3Ci%3Eu%3C/i%3E)%20and%20document%20(%3Ci%3Ed%3C/i%3E)%20latent%20factors%20as%20input%20and%20will%20output%20the%20probability%20of%20that%20specific%20user%20liking%20the%20document.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EMore%20technically,%20our%20previous%20rank%20function%20%3Ci%3Er%3C/i%3E%20w 0will%20scan%20all%20documents%20available%20and%20select%20the%20ones%20(possibly%20all)%20that%20match%20the%20query.%20When%20the%20set%20of%20documents%20matching%20a%20query%20is%20found,%20Vespa%20must%20decide%20the%20order%20of%20these%20documents.%20Unless%20explicit%20sorting%20is%20used,%20Vespa%20decides%20this%20order%20by%20calculating%20a%20number%20for%20each%20document,%20the%20rank%20score,%20and%20sorts%20the%20documents%20by%20this%20number.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20rank%20score%20can%20be%20any%20function%20that%20takes%20as%20arguments%20parameters%20sent%20by%20the%20query,%20document%20attributes%20defined%20in%20search%20definitions%20and%20global%20parameters%20not%20directly%20linked%20to%20query%20or%20document%20parameters.%20One%20example%20of%20rank%20score%20is%20the%20output%20of%20the%20neural%20network%20model%20defined%20in%20this%20tutorial.%20The%20model%20takes%20the%20latent%20factor%20%3Ci%3Eu%3C/i%3E%20associated%20with%20a%20specific%20%3Ccode%3Euser_id%3C/code%3E%20(query%20parameter),%20the%20latent%20factor%20dd%20associated%20with%20document%20%3Ccode%3Epost_id%3C/code%3E%20(document%20attribute)%20and%20learned%20model%20parameters%20(global%20parameters%20not%20related%20to%20a%20specific%20query%20nor%20document)%20and%20returns%20the%20probability%20of%20user%20%3Ci%3Eu%3C/i%3E%20to%20like%20document%20%3Ci%3Ed%3C/i%3E.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EHowever,%20even%20though%20Vespa%20is%20designed%20to%20carry%20out%20such%20calculations%20optimally,%20complex%20expressions%20becomes%20expensive%20when%20they%20must%20be%20calculated%20over%20every%20one%20of%20a%20large%20set%20of%20matching%20documents.%20To%20relieve%20this,%20Vespa%20can%20be%20configured%20to%20run%20two%20ranking%20expressions%20-%20a%20smaller%20and%20less%20accurate%20one%20on%20all%20hits%20during%20the%20matching%20phase,%20and%20a%20more%20expensive%20and%20accurate%20one%20only%20on%20the%20best%20hits%20during%20the%20reranking%20phase.%20In%20general%20thi %20neural%20network%20model%20we%20have%20trained,%20we%20need%20to%20define%20where%20to%20find%20the%20model%20parameters%20%3Ci%3E(W1,W2,b1,b2)%3C/i%3E.%20See%20the%20previous%20section%20for%20how%20to%20write%20the%20TensorFlow%20model%20parameters%20to%20Vespa%20Tensor%20format.%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3E%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0#%20We%20need%20to%20specify%20the%20type%20and%20the%20location%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0#%20of%20the%20files%20storing%20tensor%20values%20for%20each%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0#%20Variable%20in%20our%20TensorFlow%20model.%20In%20this%20case,%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0#%20W_hidden,%20b_hidden,%20W_final,%20b_final%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0constant%20W_hidden%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0file:%20constants/W_hidden.json%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0type:%20tensor(input[20],hidden[40])%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0constant%20b_hidden%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0file:%20constants/b_hidden.json%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0type:%20tensor(hidden[40])%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0constant%20W_final%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0file:%20constants/W_final.json%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0type:%20tensor(hidden[40],%20final[1])%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0constant%20b_final%20{%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0file:%20constants/b_final.json%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0type:%20tensor(final[1])%20%C2%A0%20%C2%A0}%3C/code%3E%3C/pre%3E%3Cp%3ENow,%20we%20specify%20a%20second%20rank-profile%20called%20%3Ccode%3Enn_tensor%3C/code%3E%20that%20will%20use%20the%20same%20first%20phase%20as%20the%20rank-profile%20%3Ccode%3Etensor%3C/code%3E%20but%20will%20rerank%20the%20top%20200%20documents%20using%20the%20neural%20network%20model%20as%20second%20phase.%20We%20refer%20to%20the%20%3Ca%20href=%22http://docs.vespa.ai/documentation/reference/tensor.html%22%3ETensor%20Reference%20document%3C/a%3E%20for%20more%20information%20regarding%20the%20Tensor%20operations%20used%20in%20the%20code%20below.%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3E%3Ccode%3E% let%20worked%20on%20any%20data%20source%20located%20in%20any%20persistence%20layer,%20you%20still%20had%20to%20implement%20an%20interface%20to%20connect%20your%20data%20source%20to%20the%20Backend%20and%20convert%20it%20into%20a%20record%20container%20format%20that%20Bullet%20understands.%20For%20instance,%20your%20data%20might%20be%20located%20in%20Kafka%20and%20be%20in%20the%20Avro%20format.%20If%20you%20were%20using%20Bullet%20on%20Storm,%20you%20would%20perhaps%20write%20a%20Storm%20Spout%20to%20read%20from%20Kafka,%20deserialize,%20and%20convert%20the%20Avro%20data%20into%20the%20Bullet%20record%20format.%20This%20was%20the%20only%20interface%20in%20Bullet%20that%20required%20our%20customers%20to%20write%20their%20own%20code.%20Not%20anymore!%20Bullet%20DSL%20is%20a%20text/configuration-based%20format%20for%20users%20to%20plug%20in%20their%20data%20to%20the%20Bullet%20Backend%20without%20having%20to%20write%20a%20single%20line%20of%20code.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3E%3Ca%20href=%22https://bullet-db.github.io/backend/dsl/%22%3EBullet%20DSL%3C/a%3E%20abstracts%20away%20the%20two%20major%20components%20for%20plugging%20data%20into%20the%20Bullet%20Backend.%20A%20Connector%20piece%20to%20read%20from%20arbitrary%20data-sources%20and%20a%20Converter%20piece%20to%20convert%20that%20read%20data%20into%20the%20Bullet%20record%20container.%20We%20currently%20support%20and%20maintain%20a%20few%20of%20these%20-%20Kafka%20and%20Pulsar%20for%20Connectors%20and%C2%A0Avro,%20Maps%20and%20arbitrary%20Java%20POJOs%20for%20Converters.%20The%20Converters%20understand%20typed%20data%20and%20can%20even%20do%20a%20bit%20of%20minor%20ETL%20(Extract,%20Transform%20and%20Load)%20if%20you%20need%20to%20change%20your%20data%20around%20before%20feeding%20it%20into%20Bullet.%20As%20always,%20the%20DSL%20components%20are%20pluggable%20and%20you%20can%20write%20your%20own%20(and%20contribute%20it%20back!)%20if%20you%20need%20one%20that%20we%20don%E2%80%99t%20support.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EWe%20appreciate%20your%2 ience.%20Additionally,%20our%20design%20principles%20have%20a%20strong%20focus%20on%20accessibility%20best%20practices.%20%3Cb%3E%3Cbr/%3E%3C/b%3E%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EWe%20are%20excited%20to%20share%20Denali%20with%20the%20open%20source%20community.%20We%20look%20forward%20to%20seeing%20what%20you%20build%20with%20Denali%20as%20well%20as%20your%20contributions%20and%20feedback!%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EStay%20tuned%20for%20exciting%20updates%20and%20reach%20out%20to%20us%20on%20twitter%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://twitter.com/@denali_design%22%3E@denali_design%3C/a%3E%20or%20via%20%3Ca%20href=%22mailto:denali@verizonmedia.com%22%3Eemail%3C/a%3E.%20%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3E%3Cb%3EAcknowledgments%3C/b%3E%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3E%3Ca%20href=%22https://www.linkedin.com/in/romeot/%22%3EJay%20Torres%3C/a%3E,%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://www.linkedin.com/in/chasturansky/%22%3EChas%20Turansky%3C/a%3E,%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://www.linkedin.com/in/marcosandovaldesign/%22%3EMarco%20Sandoval%3C/a%3E,%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://www.linkedin.com/in/chrisesler/%22%3EChris%20Esler%3C/a%3E,%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://www.linkedin.com/in/denchen/%22%3EDennis%20Chen%3C/a%3E,%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://www.linkedin.com/in/jon-kilroy-52545b4/%22%3EJon%20Kilroy%3C/a%3E,%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://www.linkedin.com/in/gilyehuda/%22%3EGil%20Yehuda%3C/a%3E,%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://www.linkedin.com/in/ashleywolf/%22%3EAshley%20Wolf%3C/a%3E,%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://www.linkedin.com/in/rosaliebartlett/%22%3ERosalie%20Bartlett%3C/a%3E%3C/p%3E,https://yahoodevelopers.tumblr.com/post/186682632468
mailto:?subject=Introducing%20HaloDB,%20a%20fast,%20embedded%20key-value%20storage%20engine%20written%20in%20Java&body=%3Cp%3E%3Ca%20href=%22https://yahoodevelopers.tumblr.com/post/178250134648/introducing-halodb-a-fast-embedded-key-value%22%20class=%22tumblr_blog%22%3Eyahoodevelopers%3C/a%3E:%3C/p%3E%3Cblockquote%3E%3Cp%3EBy%20Arjun%20Mannaly,%20Senior%20Software%20Engineer%C2%A0%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EAt%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://www.oath.com/our-brands/%22%3EOath%3C/a%3E,%20multiple%20ad%20platforms%20use%20a%20high%20throughput,%20low%20latency%20distributed%20key-value%20database%20that%20runs%20in%20data%20centers%20all%20over%20the%20world.%20The%20database%20stores%20billions%20of%20records%20and%20handles%20millions%20of%20read%20and%20write%20requests%20per%20second%20at%20millisecond%20latencies.%20The%20data%20we%20have%20in%20this%20database%20must%20be%20persistent,%20and%20the%20working%20set%20is%20larger%20than%20what%20we%20can%20fit%20in%20memory.%20Therefore,%20a%20key%20component%20of%20the%20database%20performance%20is%20a%20fast%20storage%20engine.%20Our%20current%20solution%20had%20served%20us%20well,%20but%20it%20was%20primarily%20designed%20for%20a%20read-heavy%20workload%20and%20its%20write%20throughput%20started%20to%20be%20a%20bottleneck%20as%20write%20traffic%20increased.%20%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThere%20were%20other%20additional%20concerns%20as%20well;%20it%20took%20hours%20to%20repair%20a%20corrupted%20DB,%20or%20iterate%20over%20and%20delete%20records.%20The%20storage%20engine%20also%20didn%E2%80%99t%20expose%20enough%20operational%20metrics.%20The%20primary%20concern%20though%20was%20the%20write%20performance,%20which%20based%20on%20our%20projections,%20would%20have%20been%20a%20major%20obstacle%20for%20scaling%20the%20database.%20With%20these%20concerns%20in%20mind,%20we%20began%20searching%20for%20an%20alternative%20solution.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EWe%20searched%20for%20a%20key-value%20storage%20engine%20capable%20of%20dealing%20with%20IO-bound%20workloads,%20with%20submillisecond%20read%20latencies%20under%20high%20read%20and%20write%20throughput.%20After%20concluding%20our%20research%20and%20benchmarking%20alternatives,%20we%20didn%E2%80%99t%20find%20a%20solution%20that%20worked%20for%20our%20workload,%20thus%20we%20were%20inspired%20to%20build%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://github.com/yahoo/HaloDB%22%3EHaloDB%3C/a%3E.%20Now,%20we%E2%80%99re%20glad%20to%20announce%20that%20it%E2%80%99s%20also%20open%20source%20and%20available%20to%20use%20under%20the%20terms%20of%20the%20Apache%20license.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EHaloDB%20has%20given%20our%20production%20boxes%20a%2050%%20improvement%20in%20write%20capacity%20while%20consistently%20maintaining%20a%20submillisecond%20read%20latency%20at%20the%2099th%20percentile.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3E%3Cb%3EArchitecture%3C/b%3E%3C/p%3E%3Cfigure%20data-orig-width=%222368%22%20data-orig-height=%221368%22%20class=%22tmblr-full%22%3E%3Cimg%20src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/04e736daa5dde2107603a9dd3dc0731c/tumblr_inline_pf9yuxWhcu1w911gs_540.png%22%20alt=%22image%22%20data-orig-width=%222368%22%20data-orig-height=%221368%22/%3E%3C/figure%3E%3Cp%3E%3Ca%20href=%22https://github.com/yahoo/HaloDB%22%3EHaloDB%3C/a%3E%20primarily%20consists%20of%20append-only%20log%20files%20on%20disk%20and%20an%20index%20of%20keys%20in%20memory.%20All%20writes%20are%20sequential%20writes%20which%20go%20to%20an%20append-only%20log%20file%20and%20the%20file%20is%20rolled-over%20once%20it%20reaches%20a%20configurable%20size.%20Older%20versions%20of%20records%20are%20removed%20to%20make%20space%20by%20a%20background%20compaction%20job.%20%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20in-memory%20index%20in%20HaloDB%20is%20a%20hash%20table%20which%20stores%20all%20keys%20and%20their%20associated%20metadata.%20The%20size%20of%20the%20in-memory%20index,%20depending%20on%20the%20number%20of%20keys,%20can%20be%20quite%20large,%20hence%20for%20performance%20reasons,%20is%20stored%20outside%20the%20Java%20heap,%20in%20native%20memory.%20When%20looking%20up%20the%20value%20for%20a%20key,%20corresponding%20metadata%20is%20first%20read%20from%20the%20in-memory%20index%20and%20then%20the%20value%20is%20read%20from%20disk.%20Each%20lookup%20request%20requires%20at%20most%20a%20single%20read%20from%20disk.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3E%3Cb%3EPerformance%20%C2%A0%3C/b%3E%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20chart%20below%20shows%20the%20results%20of%20performance%20tests%20with%20real%20production%20data.%20The%20read%20requests%20were%20kept%20at%2050,000%20QPS%20while%20the%20write%20QPS%20was%20increased.%20HaloDB%20scaled%20very%20well%20as%20we%20increased%20the%20write%20QPS%20while%20consistently%20maintaining%20submillisecond%20read%20latencies%20at%20the%2099th%20percentile.%20%3C/p%3E%3Cfigure%20data-orig-width=%221952%22%20data-orig-height=%221070%22%20class=%22tmblr-full%22%3E%3Cimg%20src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/7efd59fbfac8948311bd06b94bb13a3d/tumblr_inline_pf9yw2U2pf1w911gs_540.png%22%20alt=%22image%22%20data-orig-width=%221952%22%20data-orig-height=%221070%22/%3E%3C/figure%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20chart%20below%20shows%20the%2099th%20percentile%20latency%20from%20a%20production%20server%20before%20and%20after%20migration%20to%20HaloDB.%3C/p%3E%3Cfigure%20data-orig-width=%222092%22%20data-orig-height=%22852%22%20class=%22tmblr-full%22%3E%3Cimg%20src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/04498b8293449c7b5cec6052fa80d6e4/tumblr_inline_pf9yzvzNGz1w911gs_540.png%22%20alt=%22image%22%20data-orig-width=%222092%22%20data-orig-height=%22852%22/%3E%3C/figure%3E%3Cp%3E%C2%A0If%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://github.com/yahoo/HaloDB%22%3EHaloDB%3C/a%3E%20sounds%20like%20a%20helpful%20solution%20to%20you,%20please%20feel%20free%20to%20use%20it,%20open%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://github.com/yahoo/halodb/issues%22%3Eissues%3C/a%3E,%20and%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://github.com/yahoo/HaloDB/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md%22%3Econtribute%3C/a%3E!%3C/p%3E%3C/blockquote%3E,https://yahooeng.tumblr.com/post/178262468576
mailto:?subject=Introducing%20ONNX%20support&body=%3Cp%3E%3Cb%3EONNX%20(Open%20Neural%20Network%20eXchange)%20is%20an%20open%20format%20for%20the%20sharing%20of%20neural%20network%20and%20other%20machine%20learned%20models%20between%20various%20machine%20learning%20and%20deep%20learning%20frameworks.%20As%20the%20open%20big%20data%20serving%20engine,%20Vespa%20aims%20to%20make%20it%20simple%20to%20evaluate%20machine%20learned%20models%20at%20serving%20time%20at%20scale.%20By%20adding%20ONNX%20support%20in%20Vespa%20in%20addition%20to%20our%20existing%20TensorFlow%20support,%20we&rsquo;ve%20made%20it%20possible%C2%A0to%20evaluate%20models%20from%20all%20the%20commonly%20used%20ML%20frameworks%20with%20low%20latency%C2%A0over%20large%20amounts%20of%20data.%3C/b%3E%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EWith%20the%20rise%20of%20deep%20learning%20in%20the%20last%20few%20years,%20we&rsquo;ve%20naturally%20enough%20seen%20an%20increase%20of%20deep%20learning%20frameworks%20as%20well:%20TensorFlow,%20PyTorch/Caffe2,%20MxNet%20etc.%20One%20reason%20for%20these%20different%20frameworks%20to%20exist%20is%20that%20they%20have%20been%20developed%20and%20optimized%20around%20some%20characteristic,%20such%20as%20fast%20training%20on%20distributed%20systems%20or%20GPUs,%20or%20efficient%20evaluation%20on%20mobile%20devices.%20Previously,%20complex%20projects%20with%20non-trivial%20data%20pipelines%20have%20been%20unable%20to%20pick%20the%20best%20framework%20for%20any%20given%20subtask%20due%20to%20lacking%20interoperability%20between%20these%20frameworks.%20ONNX%20is%20a%20solution%20to%20this%20problem.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3E%3Ca%20href=%22https://onnx.ai/%22%3EONNX%3C/a%3E%20is%20an%20open%20format%20for%20AI%20models,%20and%20represents%20an%20effort%20to%20push%20open%20standards%20in%20AI%20forward.%20The%20goal%20is%20to%20help%20increase%20the%20speed%20of%20innovation%20in%20the%20AI%20community%20by%20enabling%20interoperability%20between%20different%20frameworks%20and%20thus%20streamlining%20the%20process%20of%20getting%20models%20from%20research%20to%20production.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThere%20is%20one%20commonality%20between%20the%20frameworks%20mentioned%20above%20that%20enables%20an%20open%20format%20such%20as%20ONNX,%20and%20that%20is%20that%20they%20all%20make%20use%20of%20dataflow%20graphs%20in%20one%20way%20or%20another.%20While%20there%20are%20differences%20between%20each%20framework,%20they%20all%20provide%20APIs%20enabling%20developers%20to%20construct%20computational%20graphs%20and%20runtimes%20to%20process%20these%20graphs.%20Even%20though%20these%20graphs%20are%20conceptually%20similar,%20each%20framework%20has%20been%20a%20siloed%20stack%20of%20API,%20graph%20and%20runtime.%20The%20goal%20of%20ONNX%20is%20to%20empower%20developers%20to%20select%20the%20framework%20that%20works%20best%20for%20their%20project,%20by%20providing%20an%20extensible%20computational%20graph%20model%20that%20works%20as%20a%20common%20intermediate%20representation%20at%20any%20stage%20of%20development%20or%20deployment.%20%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EVespa%20is%20an%20open%20source%20project%20which%20fits%20well%20within%20such%20an%20ecosystem,%20and%20we%20aim%20to%20make%20the%20process%20of%20deploying%20and%20serving%20models%20to%20production%20that%20have%20been%20trained%20on%20any%20framework%20as%20smooth%20as%20possible.%20Vespa%20is%20optimized%20toward%20serving%20and%20evaluating%20over%20potentially%20very%20large%20datasets%20while%20still%20responding%20in%20real%20time.%20In%20contrast%20to%20other%20ML%20model%20serving%20options,%20Vespa%20%3Ca%20href=%22http://blog.vespa.ai/post/173669458506/scaling-tensorflow-model-evaluation-with-vespa%22%3Ecan%20more%20efficiently%20evaluate%20models%20over%20many%20data%20points%3C/a%3E.%20As%20such,%20Vespa%20is%20an%20excellent%20choice%20when%20combining%20model%20evaluation%20with%20serving%20of%20various%20types%20of%20content.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EOur%20ONNX%20support%20is%20quite%20similar%20to%20our%20%3Ca%20href=%22http://blog.vespa.ai/post/171861434281/introducing-tensorflow-support%22%3ETensorFlow%20support%3C/a%3E.%20Importing%20ONNX%20models%20is%20as%20simple%20as%20adding%20the%20model%20to%20the%20Vespa%20application%20package%20(under%20&ldquo;models/&rdquo;)%20and%20referencing%20the%20model%20using%20the%20new%20ONNX%20ranking%20feature:%3C/p%3E%3Cpre%3Eexpression:%20sum(onnx(%22my_model.onnx%22))%3C/pre%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20above%20expression%20runs%20the%20model%20and%20sums%20it%20to%20a%20single%20scalar%20value%20to%20use%20in%20ranking.%20You%20will%20have%20to%20provide%20the%20inputs%20to%20the%20graph.%20Vespa%20expects%20you%20to%20provide%20a%20macro%20with%20the%20same%20name%20as%20the%20input%20tensor.%20In%20the%20macro%20you%20can%20specify%20where%20the%20input%20should%20come%20from,%20be%20it%20a%20document%20field,%20constant%20or%20a%20parameter%20sent%20along%20with%20the%20query.%20More%20information%20can%20be%20had%20%3Ca%20href=%22http://docs.vespa.ai/documentation/onnx.html%22%3Ein%20the%20documentation%20about%20ONNX%20import%3C/a%3E.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EInternally,%20Vespa%20converts%20the%20ONNX%20operations%20to%20Vespa&rsquo;s%20tensor%20API.%20We%20do%20the%20same%20for%20TensorFlow%20import.%20So%20the%20cost%20of%20evaluating%20ONNX%20and%20TensorFlow%20models%20are%20the%20same.%20We%20have%20put%20a%20lot%20of%20effort%20in%20optimizing%20the%20evaluation%20of%20tensors,%20and%20%3Ca%20href=%22http://docs.vespa.ai/documentation/onnx.html%22%3Eevaluating%20neural%20network%20models%20can%20be%20quite%20efficient%3C/a%3E.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EONNX%20support%20is%20also%20quite%20new%20to%20Vespa,%20so%20we%20do%20not%20support%20all%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://github.com/onnx/onnx/blob/master/docs/Operators.md%22%3Ecurrent%20ONNX%20operations%3C/a%3E.%20Part%20of%20the%20reason%20we%20don&rsquo;t%20support%20all%20operations%20yet%20is%20that%20some%20are%20potentially%20too%20expensive%20to%20evaluate%20per%20document,%20such%20as%20convolutional%20neural%20networks%20and%20recurrent%20networks%20(LSTMs%20etc).%20ONNX%20also%20contains%20an%20extension,%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://github.com/onnx/onnx/blob/master/docs/Operators-ml.md%22%3EONNX-ML%3C/a%3E,%20which%20contains%20additional%20operations%20for%20non-neural%20network%20cases.%20Support%20for%20this%20extension%20will%20come%20later%20at%20some%20point.%20We%20are%20continually%20working%20to%20add%20functionality,%20so%20please%20reach%20out%20to%20us%20if%20there%20is%20something%20you%20would%20like%20to%20have%20added.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EGoing%20forward%20we%20are%20continually%20working%20on%20improving%20performance%20as%20well%20as%20supporting%20more%20of%20the%20ONNX%20(and%20ONNX-ML)%20standard.%20You%20can%20read%20more%20about%20ranking%20with%20%3Ca%20href=%22http://docs.vespa.ai/documentation/onnx.html%22%3EONNX%20models%20in%20the%20Vespa%20documentation%3C/a%3E.%20We%20are%20excited%20to%20announce%20ONNX%20support.%20Let%20us%20know%20what%20you%20are%20building%20with%20it!%3C/p%3E,http://blog.vespa.ai/post/175233055656
mailto:?subject=Introducing%20Oak:%20an%20Open%20Source%20Scalable%20Key-Value%20Map%20for%20Big%20Data%20Analytics&body=%3Cp%3E%3Ca%20href=%22https://yahoodevelopers.tumblr.com/post/178045146133/introducing-oak-an-open-source-scalable-key-value%22%20class=%22tumblr_blog%22%3Eyahoodevelopers%3C/a%3E:%3C/p%3E%3Cblockquote%3E%3Cp%3EBy%20Dmitry%20Basin,%20Edward%20Bortnikov,%20Anastasia%20Braginsky,%20Eshcar%20Hillel,%20Idit%20Keidar,%20Hagar%20Meir,%20Gali%20Sheffi%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EReal-time%20analytics%20applications%20are%20on%20the%20rise.%20Modern%20decision%20support%20and%20machine%20intelligence%20engines%20strive%20to%20continuously%20ingest%20large%20volumes%20of%20data%20while%20providing%20up-to-date%20insights%20with%20minimum%20delay.%20For%20example,%20in%20%3Ca%20href=%22http://www.flurry.com/%22%3EFlurry%20Analytics%3C/a%3E,%20an%20Oath%20service%20which%20provides%20mobile%20developers%20with%20rich%20tools%20to%20explore%20user%20behavior%20in%20real%20time,%20it%20only%20takes%20seconds%20to%20reflect%20the%20events%20that%20happened%20on%20mobile%20devices%20in%20its%20numerous%20dashboards.%20The%20scalability%20demand%20is%20immense%20%E2%80%93%20as%20of%20late%202017,%20%3Ca%20href=%22http://flurrymobile.tumblr.com/post/169545749110/state-of-mobile-2017-mobile-stagnates%22%3Ethe%20Flurry%20SDK%20was%20installed%20on%202.6B%20devices%20and%20monitored%201M+%20mobile%20apps%3C/a%3E.%20Mobile%20data%20hits%20the%20Flurry%20backend%20at%20a%20huge%20rate,%20updates%20statistics%20across%20hundreds%20of%20dimensions,%20and%20becomes%20queryable%20immediately.%20Flurry%20harnesses%20the%20open-source%20distributed%20interactive%20analytics%20engine%20named%20%3Ca%20href=%22http://druid.io/%22%3EDruid%3C/a%3E%20to%20ingest%20data%20and%20serve%20queries%20at%20this%20massive%20rate.%20%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EIn%20order%20to%20minimize%20delays%20before%20data%20becomes%20available%20for%20analysis,%20technologies%20like%20Druid%20should%20avoid%20maintaining%20separate%20systems%20for%20data%20ingestion%20and%20query%20serving,%20and%20instead%20strive%20to%20do%20both%20within%20the%20same%20system.%20Doing%20so%20is%20nontrivial%20since%20one%20cannot%20compromise%20on%20overall%20correctness%20when%20multiple%20conflicting%20operations%20execute%20in%20parallel%20on%20modern%20multi-core%20CPUs.%20A%20promising%20approach%20is%20using%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://www.amazon.com/Art-Multiprocessor-Programming-Revised-Reprint/dp/0123973376%22%3Econcurrent%20data%20structure%3C/a%3E%20(CDS)%20algorithms%20which%20adapt%20traditional%20data%20structures%20to%20multiprocessor%20hardware.%20CDS%20implementations%20are%20thread-safe%20%E2%80%93%20that%20is,%20developers%20can%20use%20them%20exactly%20as%20sequential%20code%20while%20maintaining%20strong%20theoretical%20correctness%20guarantees.%20In%20recent%20years,%20CDS%20algorithms%20enabled%20dramatic%20application%20performance%20scaling%20and%20became%20popular%20programming%20tools.%20For%20example,%20Java%20programmers%20can%20use%20the%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/ConcurrentNavigableMap.html%22%3EConcurrentNavigableMap%3C/a%3E%20JDK%20implementations%20for%20the%20concurrent%20ordered%20key-value%20map%20abstraction%20that%20is%20instrumental%20in%20systems%20like%20Druid.%20%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EToday,%20we%20are%20excited%20to%20share%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://github.com/yahoo/oak%22%3EOak%3C/a%3E,%20a%20new%20open%20source%20project%20from%20Oath,%20available%20under%20the%20Apache%20License%202.0.%20The%20project%20was%20created%20by%20the%20Scalable%20Systems%20team%20at%20Yahoo%20Research.%20It%20extends%20upon%20our%20earlier%20research%20work,%20named%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=3018761%22%3EKiWi%3C/a%3E.%20%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EOak%20is%20a%20Java%20package%20that%20implements%20OakMap%20%E2%80%93%20a%20concurrent%20ordered%20key-value%20map.%20OakMap%E2%80%99s%20API%20is%20similar%20to%20Java%E2%80%99s%20ConcurrentNavigableMap.%20Java%20developers%20will%20find%20it%20easy%20to%20switch%20most%20of%20their%20applications%20to%20it.%20OakMap%20provides%20the%20safety%20guarantees%20specified%20by%20ConcurrentNavigableMap%E2%80%99s%20programming%20model.%20However,%20it%20scales%20with%20the%20RAM%20and%20CPU%20resources%20well%20beyond%20the%20best-in-class%20ConcurrentNavigableMap%20implementations.%20For%20example,%20it%20compares%20favorably%20to%20Doug%20Lea%E2%80%99s%20seminal%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/ConcurrentSkipListMap.html%22%3EConcurrentSkipListMap%3C/a%3E,%20which%20is%20used%20by%20multiple%20big%20data%20platforms,%20including%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://hbase.apache.org/%22%3EApache%20HBase%3C/a%3E,%20%3Ca%20href=%22http://druid.io/%22%3EDruid%3C/a%3E,%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://github.com/Netflix/EVCache%22%3EEVCache%3C/a%3E,%20etc.%20Our%20benchmarks%20show%20that%20OakMap%20harnesses%203x%20more%20memory,%20and%20runs%203x-5x%20faster%20on%20analytics%20workloads.%20%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EOakMap%E2%80%99s%20implementation%20is%20very%20different%20from%20traditional%20implementations%20such%20as%20%C2%A0ConcurrentSkipListMap.%20While%20the%20latter%20maintains%20all%20keys%20and%20values%20as%20individual%20Java%20objects,%20OakMap%20stores%20them%20in%20very%20large%20memory%20buffers%20allocated%20beyond%20the%20JVM-managed%20memory%20heap%20(hence%20the%20name%20Oak%20-%20abbr.%20Off-heap%20Allocated%20Keys).%20The%20access%20to%20the%20key-value%20pairs%20is%20provided%20by%20a%20lightweight%20two-level%20on-heap%20index.%20At%20its%20lower%20level,%20the%20references%20to%20keys%20are%20stored%20in%20contiguous%20chunks,%20each%20responsible%20for%20a%20distinct%20key%20range.%20The%20chunks%20themselves,%20which%20dominate%20the%20index%20footprint,%20are%20accessed%20through%20a%20lightweight%20top-level%20ConcurrentSkipListMap.%20The%20figure%20below%20illustrates%20OakMap%E2%80%99s%20data%20organization.%3C/p%3E%3Cfigure%20data-orig-width=%221280%22%20data-orig-height=%22960%22%20class=%22tmblr-full%22%3E%3Cimg%20src=%22https://66.media.tumblr.com/337ca872afdcf4b86d6a47051472a787/tumblr_inline_pf046lmN2K1w911gs_540.jpg%22%20data-orig-width=%221280%22%20data-orig-height=%22960%22/%3E%3C/figure%3E%3Cp%3E%3Ci%3EOakMap%20structure.%3C/i%3E%3Cbr/%3E%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EThe%20maintenance%20of%20OakMap%E2%80%99s%20chunked%20index%20in%20a%20concurrent%20setting%20is%20the%20crux%20of%20its%20complexity%20as%20well%20as%20the%20key%20for%20its%20efficiency.%20Experiments%20have%20shown%20that%20our%20algorithm%20is%20advantageous%20in%20multiple%20ways:%3Cbr/%3E%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3E1.%20%3Cb%3EMemory%20scaling.%20%3C/b%3EOakMap%E2%80%99s%20custom%20off-heap%20memory%20allocation%20alleviates%20the%20garbage%20collection%20(GC)%20overhead%20that%20plagues%20Java%20applications.%20Despite%20the%20permanent%20progress,%20modern%20Java%20GC%20algorithms%20do%20not%20practically%20scale%20beyond%20a%20few%20tens%20of%20GBs%20of%20memory,%20whereas%20OakMap%20scales%20beyond%20128GB%20of%20off-heap%20RAM.%20%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3E2.%20%3Cb%3EQuery%20speed.%20%3C/b%3EThe%20chunk-based%20layout%20increases%20data%20locality,%20which%20speeds%20up%20both%20single-key%20lookups%20and%20range%20scans.%20All%20queries%20enjoy%20efficient,%20cache-friendly%20access,%20in%20contrast%20with%20permanent%20dereferencing%20in%20object-based%20maps.%20On%20top%20of%20these%20basic%20merits,%20OakMap%20provides%20safe%20direct%20access%20to%20its%20chunks,%20which%20avoids%20an%20extra%20copy%20for%20rebuilding%20the%20original%20key%20and%20value%20objects.%20Our%20benchmarks%20demonstrate%20OakMap%E2%80%99s%20performance%20benefits%20versus%20ConcurrentSkipListMap:%3C/p%3E%3Cblockquote%3E%3Cp%3EA)%20Up%20to%202x%20throughput%20for%20ascending%20scans.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EB)%20Up%20to%205x%20throughput%20for%20descending%20scans.%20%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EC)%20Up%20to%203x%20throughput%20for%20lookups.%3C/p%3E%3C/blockquote%3E%3Cp%3E3.%20%3Cb%3EUpdate%20speed.%20%3C/b%3EBeyond%20avoiding%20the%20GC%20overhead%20typical%20for%20write-intensive%20workloads,%20OakMap%20optimizes%20the%20incremental%20maintenance%20of%20big%20complex%20values%20%E2%80%93%20for%20example,%20aggregate%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://datasketches.github.io/%22%3Edata%20sketches%3C/a%3E,%20which%20are%20indispensable%20in%20systems%20like%20Druid.%20It%20adopts%20in%20situ%20computation%20on%20objects%20embedded%20in%20its%20internal%20chunks%20to%20avoid%20unnecessary%20data%20copy,%20yet%20again.%20In%20our%20benchmarks,%20OakMap%20achieves%20up%20to%201.8x%20data%20ingestion%20rate%20versus%20ConcurrentSkipListMap.%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EWith%20key-value%20maps%20being%20an%20extremely%20generic%20abstraction,%20it%20is%20easy%20to%20envision%20a%20variety%20of%20use%20cases%20for%20OakMap%20in%20large-scale%20analytics%20and%20machine%20learning%20applications%20%E2%80%93%20such%20as%20unstructured%20key-value%20storage,%20structured%20databases,%20in-memory%20caches,%20parameter%20servers,%20etc.%20For%20example,%20we%20are%20already%20working%20with%20the%20Druid%20community%20on%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/pull/5732%22%3Erebuilding%20Druid%E2%80%99s%20core%20Incremental%20Index%3C/a%3E%20component%20around%20OakMap,%20in%20order%20to%20boost%20its%20scalability%20and%20performance.%20%3C/p%3E%3Cp%3EWe%20look%20forward%20to%20growing%20the%20Oak%20community!%20We%20invite%20you%20to%20explore%20the%20project,%20use%20OakMap%20in%20your%20applications,%20raise%20issues,%20suggest%20improvements,%20and%20%3Ca%20href=%22https://github.com/yahoo/Oak/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md%22%3Econtribute%20code%3C/a%3E.%20If%20you%20have%20any%20questions,%20please%20feel%20free%20to%20send%20us%20a%20note%20on%20the%20Oak%20developers%20list:%20%3Ca%20href=%22mailto:oakproject@googlegroups.com%22%3Eoakproject@googlegroups.com%3C/a%3E.%20It%20would%20be%20great%20to%20hear%20from%20you!%3C/p%3E%3C/blockquote%3E,https://yahooeng.tumblr.com/post/178045294111
